I have played 4 games so far in the Heart of the Empire campaign as one of 4 characters (3 people where one person takes 2 characters each scenario). I really had high hopes that I would like this game. I love the IP, and absolutely think Star Wars Rebellion is a fantastic game. So to be able to play a campaign game as rebel characters fighting though a "dungeon crawler" to accomplish missions seemed like an amazing experience to be had. Alas, I am so disappointed! This game is so heavily weighted in favor of the Imperial player that each scenario we Rebels are all just about killed off or have met the losing criteria by the halfway point in each scenario. And we are all fairly seasoned gamers, so it's not like we aren't familiar with the concept of action-economy, complementary abilities, buffs, etc. The Imperial Player has the advantage of knowing the map with all the tricks and traps, gets hordes of reinforcements each turn to replace the stormtroopers at a ratio of 2 to 1 it seems when/if we actually take a couple down at the start of each round, and then has some card abilities that pretty much take us out in one shot. Plus, he gets multiple dice re-rolls when at best we rebels may get 1. And then, despite all the tight action-economy and doing all you can to carefully plan your strategy each round, it all gets undone by some lousy dice rolls. Don't get me wrong, dice are not inherently a bad mechanism. But if the action economy is already super tight such that you have to be as efficient as possible to even have a 10% chance of accomplishing the mission (and I would argue 10% is generous in this game for the Rebels), then it seems majorly unfair to also be subjected to an unbalanced dice distribution where the Imperial Player's dice seem to have more ability to block your attacks than the Rebel players' dice do. Obviously there are lots of people who love this game. This is not a game for me. I do love thematic games, even those with luck (ie. Rebellion, War of the Ring 2nd Ed, Nemesis, Dead of Winter to name a few), but this is one game that I will take a hard pass on after we finish this God-forsaken campaign!

Imperial Assault is a pretty awful and vastly over hyped re-skin of Descent 2nd Edition. Sure its chromed to hell with a big grey AT-ST miniature in the box, but in terms of substance its just as awkward and shallow as D2nd. Being Star Wars themed doesn't make it any better!

Just as in D2nd they've killed all the decision making, fun and depth in the process of making a 'faster, scenario driven' game. The timed nature of many scenarios forces both sides hands tactically. You have to play cheesy tactics like blocking and stalling to win, or in the case of Rebels running away so the enemies can't touch you, both of which are frustrating to do and frustrating to have done to you. This rubbish makes every game feel like a soul destroying optimization puzzle, not a entertaining semi-coop game.

Most scenarios are totally unbalanced in favour of one side or the other.

Heroes also overdevelop into obnoxiously over complex piles of skill spaghetti ('Oh I rolled 2 hits and a surge, I'm going to use this skill to add a surge and gain focus, which in turn allows me to use my chazwaser ability to add Pierce 3 and move three spaces, I've then got within three range of a different target so I'm going to shoot them too using a special shot where I can deal damage equal to range but only if I'm stood next to another Hero in which case you can't see me to shoot me back and I deal you 9 damage pierce 3 with bleed, cleave 1 and stun'). Often Imperial player's units are essentially dead in one hit unless they get lucky and roll an evade!

As the Imperial/Overlord you're also significantly nerfed, with no real customization options. You have no event/keeper deck to build, no threat management (spawning points don't count), leaving you with few effective choices. After a point there is also little to spend experience on, as only a handful of cards will have a use depending upon your opponents. Influence cards are so hard to buy and their effects so circumstantial and weak they are hardly worth a glance a lot of the time.

All in all I just hate this game. It makes me feel miserable, bored and unhappy, regardless of which side I play on. Its as fun as throwing yourself off a building so that you land testicles first on a railing.

My favourite moment in the whole game was when the heroes lost the campaign and they were hanged on gallows like 1700s sheep rustlers. I laughed, laughed like Jack Nicholson Joker when he looks in the mirror.

Imperial Assault is a dungeon crawler, but with a Star Wars theme. Is the IP enough to make this feel different or exciting?

Unfortunately for me, I do not feel much enthusiasm for the game even though I love the Star Wars universe. I was hoping this would be a great romp, but unfortunately, move and roll dice to attack just doesn’t do it for me. I feel like I am doing the exact same things every turn.

There is very little dice mitigation in this one. If you have one bad roll, then you may be toast. I struggle with dice battling games in general because they feel so unpredictable and can have such swingy results.

Compare that to Gloomhaven, where you can get items, do different attacks, and guarantee damage based on cards that you play. Each turn feels different because you are managing a deck. You have items that allow for one-offs. You can remove negative cards from your deck. I feel a greater sense of control in Gloomhaven which is why I appreciate that property more than Imperial Assault.

I have only played two missions where my entire experience was dependent on getting a certain roll. In fact, I only had 3.75% probability of not winning the second one. Sure enough, I rolled the wrong thing and lost. This is a memorably painful experience, and a great one for the other player, but can really dampen enthusiasm after a two hour experience comes down to that.

BGG stats on balance of the campaign seems to show it's incredibly lopsided in favor of the Imperial player. Maybe there are better scenarios out there. I’ll likely try one or two more scenarios, but starting to wain early in enthusiasm for this one.

As we continued to play scenarios, again and again we had turns where a dice roll went awry. Or, we had some modifier that changed something completely, adding strain or damage.

Last gripe, but it's a big one with many fantasy flight properties and Corey Konieczka in particular: when every round I have to ruin the game flow to consult a bgg forum or to look up something in a reference rulebook that was not clear in the main rulebook, then your instruction guides have issues. In every campaign scenario we played, something was always unclear on the main instructions. I found answers buried in the "encyclopedia" reference rulebook, or online, or not at all and we just decided to move on. This is maddening to what already feels like a frustrating experience with unsatisfying dice rolls.

Maybe I would be willing to give this another chance with more balanced scenarios or some new expansion property, but I can think of other properties I'd rather be playing.

This is the prime example of what I do *not* want of a board game: tons of components, which translates into excruciating set-up times and even more bookkeeping. You spend almost as much time doing chores than actually playing. Also, the so-called "narrative" comes from someone reading a rulebook out loud, and has close to no emergent narrative whatsoever.

If this were a digital game, it could be played in ten minutes due to the lack of set up and bookkeeping. All that said, if you are a Star Wars fan and don't mind the downtime, do give it a try.

Regardless, the minis are nice, the levels are well designed, the changes to the rules drastically improve the game system over it's mechanical predecessor, Descent 2nd edition. The huge improvements include having players take turns between monster activations, moving the miss result onto the defense die that the lighter armored characters roll, as opposed to having it on the attack die, and in general, the theme fits the timed-style maps much better than a Dungeon Crawl setting does. That being said, my playgroup took issue with the timed missions aspect of things. For them, this game needed to be more of a monster-masher for them to enjoy it. Pity.

Finally got around to playing this game. Although I usually prefer a fantasy theme for dungeon crawlers and was a bit wary of the Star Wars IP, this turned out to be a great success! It didn’t really feel like a typical dungeon crawl, but more like a series of missions that fit together into a cohesive story. It’s also a clear improvement on the Descent system.
The miss die has been removed from the attacker’s pool and instead added to the defender’s roll — a small change, but definitely an improvement. The updated line of sight rules are a real gift and put an end to so many debates.
Playing as the Imperial side was much more fun than acting as a traditional DM. The class decks, agenda decks, and threat system were all excellent additions.
And, surprisingly, our group connected with this game even more than with a typical fantasy setting. Seeing Han Solo in the cantina or facing off against Tusken Raiders sparked so many fun references to the films — it really brought the experience to life!

 A double rulebook system: Learn to Play + Rules Reference Guide. This wouldn't work well with many other games, but it does in this FFG title. It reminds me a bit of the video game approach, where more gameplay abilities are unlocked as the game's storyline progresses. Here you start playing after reading through the Learn to Play booklet, and when you encounter a situation that isn't covered there, you look it up in the Rules Reference Guide. The latter comes with a useful index and a good cross-reference system between related items. But as a rulebook in itself, it's a mess. It's a bit of a nuisance to read it as is. And if you don't encounter the situations that prompt you to look up a rule in there, it's possible that you'll be playing without an essential (albeit often small) rule unwittingly...

----

 So. Many. Expansions. It's a double-edged knife. Granted, you're not obliged to buy any expansions. You can use tokens, and the stat cards are provided in the game (and campaign expansion boxes). But you'll want them, 'cause you're a Star Wars fan. But then you'll have the luxury problem of finding storage for all those miniatures (especially if you paint them), cards, and tokens. And the choices: what card decks will I use in my campaign?
Which figures? For Skirmish, it's a lot of fun to be able to build a wide variety of teams, of course.

 I find Campaign games to be a tad 'bittersweet'. Playing as a campaign adds an extra dimension to the gameplay of any game. Your sessions feel like part of a greater whole; your actions are steps towards something beyond the current scenario. But it adds more 'scheduling' to your free time. The schedules of a campaign group need to align, and that's not something that's easily doable for some people. I have started multiple campaigns, but haven't seen even one of them all the way through to the end... And story-wise, the patchwork of story missions and side missions often provides a narrative that doesn't make all that much sense. Though I must add that each mission on its own really does feel like Star Wars.

I own every expansion and most of the playmats. I've been to multiple tournaments and played basically everything. IA absolutely has its faults: Skirmish can go on a little long, is very difficult to balance, and can be clunky to understand the proper technique for; Campaign is unbalanced, some missions feel a bit samey, and the rules are sometimes confusing and pointless; Co-op is lacking in content and the app has a few weird rules that are difficult to remember. However, the theme is incredible, the core rules are very tightly designed, it's easy to teach, very difficult to master, and most of all, there's something for everyone here. You could buy every expansion and exclusively play campaign and still get your money's worth out of this game. You could also never play campaign once and still get your money's worth. At $100 original retail price this game is more than a steal, and every expansion pushed the game forward in a meaningful way. The monetization of these expansions is also extremely buyer friendly as the lowest value boxes are also the least essential. I would recommend Imperial Assault to everyone, unless the theme truly does nothing for you, or you have an extremely low tolerance for clunky rules. This is my favorite game of all time.
